messageBody:
Hi Cedric, Chris, Simon,

On 8/28/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On 8/28/06, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:
> > On 8/28/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> > > On 8/27/06, Chris Barham <cbarham@...> wrote:
> > > > pass it a mock connection which has an expectation of a call on to the
> > > > close method.
> > >
> > > The danger with this approach is that if you upgrade your JDBC driver
> > > and that in the new version, close() is broken, your test will keep
> > > passing but your application will break...
> >
> > But are we supposed to be testing our tools or our code?
>
> We are supposed to make sure that if our tests pass, our code will work.
> [...]
> I agree that in general, you should trust the layers you rely on, but if
> there is an easy way to test them as well, then why not do that instead of
> relying on mock objects that will lull you into a false sense of confidence?

...or use the mock connection for verifying that your code interacts
with the 3rd party API (JDBC driver) as expected and write a small set
of focused integration tests for testing your assumptions about the
3rd party API.

-Lasse-
